member.name: T:Microsoft.Fabric.Utilities.CompatibilityClaimConverter
member.summary: The internals of System.Security.Claims.Claim class changed between net472 and .NET. That is a problem when we use the out-of-the-box json formatter to write a .NET Claim object and try to read it in net472, as we're using the internal field names. This converter reads and writes .NET Claims the same way as net472 Claims.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Fabric.Utilities.CompatibilityClaimConverter.Read(System.Text.Json.Utf8JsonReader@,System.Type,System.Text.Json.JsonSerializerOptions)
member.summary: Reads a Claim object from a JSON string.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Fabric.Utilities.CompatibilityClaimConverter.Write(System.Text.Json.Utf8JsonWriter,System.Security.Claims.Claim,System.Text.Json.JsonSerializerOptions)
member.summary: Writes a Claim object to a JSON stream.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Fabric.Utilities.NetworkUtils.GetFreePort
member.summary: Gets the next free port from the ephemeral port range.
member.remarks: The function uses underlying OS to assign a port and relies on the fact that OS will cycle through the rest of the ephemeral ports before assigning the same port again. In rare cases there can still be a race condition so callers need to be prepared to handle that.

member.summary: Not defined.

member.summary: Workload is trusted.

member.summary: Workload is untrusted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadLifecycleType
member.summary: Defines the lifecycle type of workload.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadLifecycleType.Classic
member.summary: Classic lifetime management that is used today

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadLifecycleType.Hybrid
member.summary: The upcoming way that is vaguely defined so far. One example of Hybrid is 3rd party workloads hosted in external infra and managed either through relay or directly via https. In future workloads utilizing this lifecycle can be hosted in a container in MWC internal infra.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadRunningMode
member.summary: Defines possible running modes/configurations that workloads can use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadRunningMode.Relay
member.summary: Also know n as development experience mode. Under this mode workload is hosted in external infra while communication/lifecycle is facilitated by Azure Relay.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadRunningMode.External
member.summary: Under this mode workload is hosted in external infra while communication/lifecycle is based on https.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadRunningMode.Container
member.summary: Workload is hosted in internal MWC infra while running inside container.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadTrustLevel
member.summary: Defines the trust level of the workload.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadTrustLevel.FirstParty
member.summary: Workloads created and maintained internally.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Fabric.Workloads.WorkloadTrustLevel.ThirdParty
member.summary: Workloads created and maintained by external engineering teams.
